questions.question: According to the laws of thermodynamics, which of the following is NOT true?

answers.text: If two bodies are each in thermal equilibrium with a third body, they are also in equilibrium with each other.
Energy can be converted from one form to another but cannot be created nor destroyed.
The entropy of the universe increases in an equilibrium process and remains unchanged in a spontaneous process.
The entropy of a system approaches a constant value when absolute temperature reaches absolute zero.

questions.question: Which of the following amino acids is a polar, nonessential, weakly acidic amino acid with an aromatic side chain?
Denaturation of proteins will most probably hydrolyze the following bonds that stabilize the structure of proteins, EXCEPT:
This autosomal dominant disorder will have an earlier onset and more severe presentation in successive generations, a phenomenon known as:
Which statement describes hemoglobin as compared to myoglobin?

answers.text: Demonstrates a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve
Main purpose is for oxygen storage

questions.question: A 3-year-old male is brought to the clinic by his mother due to irritability, bleeding gums, and bruises. Ancillary history revealed updated immunization, normal growth and development, and diet consisting mainly of milk, bread, and snacks. Notable physical examination findings include dry skin, petechiae and ecchymoses on lower limbs, corkscrew hair, and swollen, bleeding gums. Based on these signs and symptoms, the underlying pathogenesis involves a defect in which collagen synthesis step?

answers.text: Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues
Cleavage of C and N terminal peptides

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE of Marfan Syndrome?

answers.text: Mutation of FBN1 gene on chromosome 15, which results in defective fibrillin-1, a glycoprotein that forms a sheath around collagen
Presents with hypermobile joints, long and tapering fingers and toes, and short stature
Vascular complications to watch out include aortic root dilatation and aortic dissection

questions.question: Which sugar will yield a negative Benedict’s test?
Hyperglycemia in Type 1 diabetes mellitus may be attributed to decreased function of which glucose transporters?
Which of the following is TRUE regarding classification of fatty acids?

answers.text: Saturated fatty acids have at least one double bond in the hydrocarbon chain
In the trans form of fatty acids, H atoms are found on the opposite side
Non-essential fatty acids include linoleic acid and alpha-linolenic acid
Very long chain fatty acids are those with 16 to 20 carbon atoms in the chain

questions.question: Which of the following enzymes catalyzes the reaction that generates pregnenolone, the ""mother of all steroid hormones""?

answers.text: Side chain cleavage cytochrome p450 enzyme
No enzyme is involved in the synthesis of pregnenolone

questions.question: Which molecule or compound will contribute to both purine and pyrimidine rings?
The bonds between phosphate groups in a nucleotide are:
Applying Chargaff’s rule, if a sample of DNA has 26% of guanine, what will be the amount (in %) of adenine present in the sample?
Type of RNA which contains significant proportions of nucleosides with unusual bases, including inosine, pseudouridine, dihydrouridine, and ribothymidine

A 2-year-old male patient is brought to the clinic due to progressive weight loss and difficulty of feeding, which started three months ago. Patient had no significant illnesses but had recurrent episodes of diarrhea in the past two months. Ancillary history is unremarkable, except for diet which mainly consists of lugaw, black tea, and occasional saba. Physical examination reveals dry, wrinkled, and loose skin over the buttocks and thighs, markedly reduced muscle mass, sunken eyes, prominent bones, and flat abdomen. WFH z-score is less than -3 SD. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following is most probably TRUE about this patient?

answers.text: Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following is most probably TRUE about this patient?
This is mainly due to caloric deprivation
The underlying pathology is probably genetic in origin
Mid-upper arm circumference is most likely normal

questions.question: Which of the following macronutrients contains the most amount of kilocalories per gram?
This measure of protein quality is the ratio of nitrogen used for tissue formation to the nitrogen absorbed from food:
Which component of breast milk promotes growth and maturation of newborn intestinal mucosa?
A patient with Shwachman-Diamond syndrome will most likely have a deficiency in:

A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to headaches, vomiting, new onset blurring of vision, and dry skin. Ancillary history is unremarkable except for increased intake of vitamin supplements to “strengthen” the immune system. On PE, papilledema and mild hepatomegaly were noted. Based on the clinical findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?

answers.text: Acute exacerbation of chronic pancreatic insufficiency

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy with cystic fibrosis presents with muscle weakness, ataxia, frequent falls, and poor coordination. PE reveals decreased deep tendon reflexes, impaired proprioception, and mild muscle weakness. CBC shows mild normocytic, normochromic anemia, and examination of peripheral blood smear shows red blood cells with irregular pointed projections extending from their surface. Based on the clinical findings, the most likely treatment for his symptoms is:

answers.text: Transfusion of properly typed and crossmatched blood

questions.question: Which of the following is increased in response to hypercalcemic states?
Vitamin C plays a role in the following biochemical processes, EXCEPT:

answers.text: Hydroxylation of lysine and proline residues in collagen synthesis
Conversion of ferric to ferrous ions, which facilitates iron absorption
Conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine via dopamine β-hydroxylase

questions.question: A 64-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of a symmetrical, red, scaly rash on the hands, face, and neck, along with frequent watery diarrhea and increasing forgetfulness. His diet mainly consists of corn and corn products. Physical exam reveals a broad collar rash, hyperpigmentation of sun- exposed limbs, and mild disorientation. Similar symptoms may be found in a patient with:
Which of the following is TRUE of folate deficiency compared to cobalamin deficiency?

answers.text: In its severe form, it may manifest with subacute combined neurologic degeneration
It will have increased methylmalonic acid compared to cobalamin deficiency
It is directly involved in the pathogenesis of pernicious anemia
Folate stores in the body will deplete faster than cobalamin stores

questions.question: Where is the major site of absorption of iron?
Copper plays a role in the following processes, EXCEPT:

answers.text: Oxidation of iron from ferrous to ferric form
Formation of crosslinks in collagen and elastin fibers
Conversion of superoxide to hydrogen peroxide

questions.question: Which of the following pairings is mismatched?

answers.text: Hydrolases – cleave substrate bonds using water
Ligases – catalyzes the cleavage of C-C, C-S, and certain C-N bonds
Lyases – catalyze non-hydrolytic reactions in which groups (like CO2 and NH3) are removed

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true of competitive enzyme inhibition?

answers.text: The maximal velocity of the reaction is unchanged
Reversal of the inhibition can be achieved by increasing enzyme concentration
An example is the effect of atorvastatin on cholesterol synthesis

questions.question: Which of the following metabolic pathway-rate- limiting enzyme pairings is mismatched?
Which is true of protein digestion?

answers.text: Pepsinogen is autocatalytically cleaved to pepsin at alkaline pH
Enterokinase is activated by the presence of proteins in the lumen of the small intestine
Trypsin is converted to trypsinogen to cleave the rest of the inactivated pancreatic proenzymes
Absorption of amino acids, dipeptides, and tripeptides happen via simple diffusion

questions.question: What are the products of lactose hydrolysis?
Which enzyme catalyzes the hydrolysis of triglycerides stored in adipocytes as a response to low-energy states?

A 6-month-old male with history of tetralogy of Fallot and recurrent infections since birth comes to the clinic for follow-up. History shows hypocalcemic seizures, three episodes of pneumonia, persistent oral thrush, and mild developmental delay. PE reveals a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border, cleft palate, and mild hypotonia. The underlying pathology is most likely:

answers.text: Failure of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches to develop
Complete lack of immunoglobulin due to disordered B-cell maturation
X-linked mutation in the WASP gene

questions.question: Activation of the classical complement cascade is triggered by:

answers.text: Antigen-antibody complexes on bacterial cell surface
Any foreign cell surface components such as those of microorganisms
Binding of spontaneously produced C3b to a bacterial cell surface
The binding of mannan-binding lectin to target cell membrane

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding immunoglobulins is INCORRECT?

answers.text: IgG is the smallest antibody and provides immune protection to the fetus through placental transfer
IgA is found in body secretions and prevents attachment of bacteria and viruses to mucous membranes
IgM activates mast cells and basophils to release inflammatory mediators to help eliminate allergens
The best antibody that must be detected in recognizing congenital infections is IgM

questions.question: A 33-year-old male comes for a consult for persistent fatigue, dark-colored urine in the morning, and exertional dyspnea. He reports intermittent dark urine for the past few months, especially after waking up. No fever, recent infections, nor new medications. PE is unremarkable except for pallor. Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin of 8.4 g/dL, increased LDH, low haptoglobin, and elevated indirect bilirubin. Coombs test is negative. Urinalysis shows hemoglobinuria but no proteinuria nor RBCs on microscopic exam. Based on the given data, what is the most likely pathophysiology?

answers.text: Extravascular hemolysis due to enzyme deficiency
Intravascular hemolysis due to traumatic forces
Anemia due to decreased RBC production resulting from a vitamin or mineral deficiency

questions.question: According to the Expanded National Nutrition Survey, what is the most prevalent micronutrient deficiency in the Philippines?
Which of the following compounds will be produced through the hydrolysis of ATP and is not used to regenerate ATP?
Which of the following inhibits the electron transport chain by directly inhibiting Complex V?
Which part of the electron transport chain transfers electrons from FADH₂ to ubiquinone?
Which statement is true of hexokinase as compared to glucokinase?

answers.text: Present only in liver parenchymal cells and beta cells of the pancreas
Has low receptor affinity and high Km
Has lower capacity and lower Vmax

questions.question: The following coenzymes are required for pyruvate to proceed to the Citric Acid Cycle, EXCEPT:
Which enzyme used in glycolysis catalyzes the reaction that generates NADH?
Rate-limiting step of the citric acid cycle:
The following cells can generate ATP using the citric acid cycle, EXCEPT:
Which intermediate of the citric acid cycle can be used for heme synthesis and activation of ketone bodies in extrahepatic tissues?
What coenzyme is required in the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate?
Gluconeogenesis is stimulated by the hormonal effects of glucagon through this mechanism:

answers.text: Formation of pyruvate as the end product of the pathway
Increased synthesis and activation of phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase
Phosphorylation and activation of phosphofructokinase-2 kinase domain

questions.question: Which of the following generates substrates for gluconeogenesis?
Which of the following regulators inhibit glycogenesis?
What is the product of glycogenolysis in skeletal muscle?

A 5-month-old infant is brought to the clinic due to persistent irritability, distended abdomen, and poor weight gain. The parents report that the child becomes very fussy and sweaty a few hours after feeding. PE reveals hepatomegaly and a round, doll- like face. Laboratory tests reveal severe fasting hypoglycemia, elevated lactate, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this case?
Which of the following is an allosteric activator of glycogenolysis in the muscle?
Which enzyme is deficient in classic galactosemia?

Accumulation of sorbitol in patients with diabetes leads to retinopathy, neuropathy, and nephropathy. What enzyme, which is deficient in the lens, retina, and kidney, catalyzes the conversion of sorbitol to fructose?
The non-oxidative and reversible phase of the Pentose Phosphate pathway is important for:

answers.text: Formation of 2,3-DPG to facilitate oxygen distribution

questions.question: A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency department with dark-colored urine, fatigue, and jaundice. Two days prior, he was prescribed unrecalled antibiotics for a urinary tract infection. Past medical history revealed no history of anemia but recalls similar symptoms when exposed to mothballs. PE is unremarkable except for mild jaundice. Lab tests show Hgb 9.0 g/dL, increased reticulocyte count, increased LDH, and increased indirect bilirubin. The underlying biochemical mechanism of the patient’s condition is:
Acetyl CoA carboxylase is activated by:
Further elongation and desaturation of fatty acids occur in which organelle?
Which of the following statements is TRUE of beta- oxidation as compared to lipogenesis?

answers.text: It involves cycles of condensation-reduction- dehydration-reduction processes
It is inhibited by high levels of Malonyl CoA
It happens in the cytosol and uses the citrate shuttle to transport Acetyl CoA to the cytosol

questions.question: A 2-month-old infant presents with poor feeding, failure to thrive, and developmental delay. He was reported to have difficulty holding up his head and making eye contact. PE shows a high forehead, shallow orbits, hypertelorism, high arched palate, abnormal helices of ears, and retrognathia. Labs reveal elevated liver enzymes, and imaging shows enlarged adrenal glands. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of an autosomal recessive defect in a gene that codes for peroxisome synthesis. Metabolism of which of the following is impaired in this case?
What is the substrate for ketogenesis?
Which ketone body constitutes the highest percentage in urine, but is undetectable by conventional methods that use sodium nitroprusside?

answers.text: All are present in equal amounts

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT TRUE regarding cholesterol synthesis?

answers.text: Acetoacetyl-CoA and Acetyl CoA condense to form HMG-CoA via the action of HMG-CoA reductase
HMG-CoA reductase is the rate-limiting step of de novo cholesterol synthesis
Squalene becomes the cyclic compound lanosterol through the action of cyclase
Insulin and thyroxine upregulate the expression of the HMG CoA reductase gene

questions.question: A 5-day-old female newborn is brought to the emergency department for poor feeding, vomiting, and lethargy. PE shows hypotension and dehydration. External genitalia appear ambiguous with clitoromegaly and partial fusion of the labia. Laboratory studies reveal hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypoglycemia. Which enzyme deficiency is most commonly implicated in the case?
This lipoprotein is important in the transport of endogenous triglycerides:
Which apolipoprotein is found mainly in HDL and activates lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT)?

A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for recurrent abdominal pain and vomiting. Past medical history reveals recurrent pancreatitis. PE shows xanthomas over his elbows and knees and marked hepatosplenomegaly. Lipid profile shows markedly elevated triglycerides (1104 mg/dL), low LDL, and low HDL, with the plasma sample reportedly having a creamy supernatant upon refrigeration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which coenzyme is required for transamination reactions?
Which of the following statements is NOT TRUE regarding the urea cycle?

answers.text: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I is the rate- limiting step
The substrates are ammonia, aspartate, and carbon dioxide
It is allosterically inactivated by N- acetylglutamate
The goal is to convert the body’s nitrogenous waste to urea, which may be safely excreted in the urine

questions.question: A 4-day-old male neonate is brought to the emergency department due to poor feeding, lethargy, and vomiting. Antenatal course was unremarkable. On PE, he is somnolent with signs of encephalopathy. Laboratory tests reveal hyperammonemia, respiratory alkalosis, and normal glucose levels. Serum amino acid analysis shows low citrulline, with markedly elevated urine orotic acid. There is no history of liver disease. Genetic testing will likely reveal a defect in the gene which codes for this enzyme:
Which of the following amino acids may be converted to acetyl CoA but may not be converted to pyruvate or intermediates of the citric acid cycle?
Which enzyme catalyzes the conversion of Normetanephrine and Metanephrine to Vanillylmandelic acid?
Which of the following pairings is mismatched?
In Maple Syrup Urine Disease, urine levels of which of the following are significantly elevated and is associated with neurologic symptoms?

Ben is a 44-year-old man with a 5-month history of blistering cutaneous photosensitivity on the backs of his hands and forearms, which is more notable after sun exposure. He also reports tea-colored urine. Past medical history reveals chronic hepatitis C and alcohol use disorder. PE shows hyperpigmentation, scarring, and healing vesicles on sun-exposed areas. Lab work shows elevated ALT and AST, and a 24-hour urine sample fluoresces pink under UV light. Based on the given data, the most likely affected enzyme is:
Which of the following hyperbilirubinemia syndromes will present with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
After how many hours of fasting will gluconeogenesis take over as the major source of fuel in the body?
What is the precursor amino acid of NAD+?

A 45-year-old male patient comes to the clinic due to a 6-month history of increasing fatigue and reduced libido. He also has joint pain in both of his hands. Vital signs are within normal limits. PE shows diffuse hyperpigmentation and decreased size of the testes. The 2nd and 3rd MCP joints of both hands are tender to palpation and have limited range of motion. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. Lab results show elevated ferritin, increased liver enzymes, and fasting glucose of 250 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare recessively inherited disease with dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia due to impaired absorption of what mineral?
Most abundant glycosaminoglycan in the body:

A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to progressive developmental delay, hirsutism, coarse facial features, and frequent URTIs. He was noted to have increasing irritability and has stiff joints and enlarging head size, but has no aggressive behavior. PE shows frontal bossing, elongated skull, thickened gingiva, and corneal clouding. X-ray shows dysostosis multiplex.  Urine tests demonstrate elevated levels of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. The most probable diagnosis is:
Which of the following disease – enzyme deficiency pairings is mismatched?

A 6-year-old Ashkenazi Jewish boy presents with hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, growth delay, and extreme bone pain. Bone marrow staining shows lipid-laden macrophages resembling crumpled tissue paper. What is the likely diagnosis?
What is the enzyme needed by the salvage pathway for the synthesis of purine ribonucleotides?
Which of the following statements regarding drugs that inhibit nucleotide metabolism is correct?

A 10-month-old boy is brought to the clinic due to intellectual disability, aggression, poor motor development, and involuntary movements. He was noted to bite his lips and fingers, leaving visible wounds. He was also noted to have delayed milestones and increased irritability. Further questioning reveals that the patient has a maternal uncle who died early in childhood with the same symptoms. On PE, the patient is hypotonic and has dystonia and ulcerations on his lips and hands. Diaper was noted to have red-orange sandy material. Lab works show elevated serum uric acid and uric acid crystals on urine microscopy. Based on the case, the likely explanation for the patient’s hyperuricemia is:

answers.text: Underexcretion of uric acid in the urine
Increase in de novo purine synthesis due to defective purine salvage pathway
Diversion of glycolysis to the pentose phosphate pathway, leading to increased de novo purine synthesis
Massive breakdown of nucleic acids secondary to cell lysis

questions.question: What are Okazaki fragments?

answers.text: RNA primers used to initiate DNA replication
Short DNA fragments synthesized on the lagging strand
Enzyme complexes involved in DNA repair
Segments of RNA spliced from pre-mRNA

questions.question: In prokaryotes, this enzyme removes RNA nucleotides of primer from the 5’ end and replaces them with DNA nucleotides; this enzyme has 5’ to 3’ exonuclease activity:

A 41-year-old male is being evaluated after his younger sister was recently diagnosed with colorectal cancer at 33 years old. He is currently asymptomatic, but has a strong family history of colon, endometrial, and ovarian cancers on the maternal side which were all diagnosed before 50 years of age. Colonoscopy reveals a right-sided colon CA. Immunohistochemical staining of the tumor shows loss of MLH1 and PMS2 expression. The DNA repair mechanism which is defective in this case is:

answers.text: Immunohistochemical staining of the tumor shows loss of MLH1 and PMS2 expression. The DNA repair mechanism which is defective in this case is:

questions.question: The genetic code is degenerate, meaning:

answers.text: Multiple codons may code for the same amino acid
A specific codon always codes for the same amino acid
The codons are read in a continuing sequence of nucleotide triplets until a translation stop codon is reached
It has been conserved from very early stages of evolution with only slight differences in the manner in which the code is translated

questions.question: Sickle cell disease is a type of anemia in which the glutamic acid at position 6 of the beta globin chain becomes valine, leading to production of Hemoglobin S instead of Hemoglobin A. This is what kind of mutation?

answers.text: This is what kind of mutation?

questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding transcription?

answers.text: Introns contain the actual genetic information coding for protein or functional RNA
Exons do not code for protein, but are important in regulation of gene expression
RNA polymerase binds to DNA promoter sequences to initiate RNA synthesis
RNA polymerase proceeds in the 3’ to 5’ direction

questions.question: A 55-year-old man dies due to a 20-year progressive illness characterized by athetoid movements and deterioration leading to hypertonicity, fecal and urine incontinence, anorexia and weight loss, and eventually dementia and death. Chromosomal studies have revealed CAG repeats on chromosome
Which antibiotic inhibits protein synthesis by inhibiting prokaryotic peptidyltransferase?

A 55-year-old male has recently been diagnosed with leukemia. To localize the specific gene abnormality and directly visualize the translocation at a molecular level, which technique is most appropriate to use?
Which technique may be used as confirmatory test by detecting the presence or absence of antibodies against Borrelia in the diagnosis of Lyme disease?
Which of the following is a prion-like disease?
Regarding enzyme kinetics, which of the following statements accurately describes the Michaelis- Menten constant (Km)?

answers.text: Km is inversely proportional to enzyme affinity for substrate.
Km represents the maximum velocity of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction.
A lower Km indicates higher substrate affinity.
Km is not affected by changes in enzyme concentration.

questions.question: The following are characteristics of glucokinase EXCEPT:

answers.text: It removes glucose from the blood following a meal, providing glucose-6-phosphate in excess of requirements for glycolysis.
It has a Km that is lower than the normal intracellular concentration of glucose.
It has a high Vmax, which allows it to effectively remove glucose.
It functions in the liver parenchymal cells and the B cells of the pancreas.

questions.question: Fetal hemoglobin shifts the oxygen saturation curve in what direction?
Which is NOT a co-factor required for the citric acid cycle?
Which is NOT a component of heme?
Which of the following is the earliest sign of Vitamin A deficiency?
What is the volume of plasma in 500 mL of blood?
Which of the following would exhibit diet-induced thermogenesis?
What is the type of whey protein found in human breastmilk?
What is the whey content of cow’s milk?
Which mineral co-factor is associated with glutathione peroxidase?
Red blood cells compose what percentage of total blood volume?
Which of the following enzymes acts as an antioxidant for superoxides?
What amino acids has an absorbance of light at 290 nm?
Which amino acid acts as the carrier of ammonia from muscle to liver?
Which cells are enlarged in hyperthyroidism?
Which of the following antibodies may exist as a tetramer?
Which of the following compounds are derived from arachidonic acid?
In which of the following conditions are ketone bodies NOT produced?
Which of the following compounds can be digested by salivary amylase?
Apocrine glands can be located in which part of the body?
Which of the following amino acids can be synthesized in the body?
In diabetic patients, which enzyme is involved in the breakdown of excess glucose and the subsequent formation of cataracts when deficient?
Among the following, which substance specifically impacts the afferent arteriole in the kidney?
Acarbose, a drug that acts on carbohydrate breakdown and aids in the control of post-meal blood glucose levels in diabetics, acts via what specific mechanism?
In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, the x-axis represents:
Melatonin, a hormone crucial for regulating sleep- wake cycles, is derived from which amino acid?
Which of the following factors is not typically associated with overnutrition and obesity?

A 32-year-old female presents with irregular menstrual cycles and milky discharge from her breasts. Laboratory tests reveal elevated prolactin levels. The pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following pharmacological treatment is often considered as first-line therapy for this condition?
The following are considered as secondary structures in proteins EXCEPT:
Structure in proteins that are preserved during the process of denaturation:
Which among the given types of bilirubin is known for its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier and is implicated in causing kernicterus?
Heme synthesis occurs in the following EXCEPT:

After an intense workout, a marathon runner experiences muscle fatigue and produces excess lactate. In the liver, the lactate is converted into glucose to provide energy source for the muscle tissues. Which metabolic process best describes this pathway?
Which of the following is considered an alcohol  safe for consumption in beverages?
The following are effects of DHEA EXCEPT:
Which of the following processes is responsible for donating high-energy phosphate?
Which of the following is involved  in combining two molecules via  ATP hydrolysis?
The major form of vitamin D is synthesized in the:
Subunit found in Hemoglobin A2:
In the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which cofactor is derived from pantothenic acid?
Which of the following would increase insulin secretion?
Vitamin K is mainly absorbed in the:
Aromatization of androstenedione would yield which of the following?
Which of the following contributes to “folding” in insulin?
Which amino acid can be used exclusively as a source for the synthesis of ketone bodies?
Which of the following hormones uses G-protein coupled receptor?
Which cell can use only glucose for energy needs?
In the context of protein folding, what is the role of chaperone proteins?

answers.text: Chaperone proteins catalyze peptide bond formation.
Chaperone proteins prevent protein misfolding and aggregation.
Chaperone proteins are involved only in protein degradation.
Chaperone proteins stabilize the tertiary structure of proteins.

questions.question: In eukaryotic cells, what is the role of the 5' cap and poly-A tail in mRNA?

answers.text: They are essential for the recognition of the start codon during translation.
They protect the mRNA from degradation and enhance its stability.
They facilitate the binding of ribosomes to the mRNA.
They code for specific amino acids in the translated protein.

questions.question: Which of the following mechanisms is involved in translational control of gene expression?
In the context of protein synthesis, what is the role of the signal recognition particle (SRP)?

answers.text: SRP is involved in the recognition of start codons.
SRP facilitates the translocation of ribosomes along mRNA.
SRP guides ribosomes to the endoplasmic reticulum during co-translational protein targeting.
SRP promotes the termination of translation.

questions.question: During transcriptional regulation, what is the function of histone acetylation?

answers.text: Histone acetylation promotes the condensation of chromatin.
Histone acetylation enhances gene expression by loosening chromatin structure.
Histone acetylation repairs damaged DNA strands.

questions.question: What substance is detected by a northern blot?
Which blood type is termed the universal blood acceptor?
Which food group has the highest caloric content?
Which genetic problem results in the Fragile X syndrome?
What is the rate-determining enzyme of fatty acid synthesis?
What immune cells predominantly produce cytokines?
Which statement is TRUE for Menkes disease?

answers.text: Menkes disease is caused by a defect in the ATP7A gene.
Menkes disease is associated with the storage of Cu in parenchyma of different organs.
Menkes disease is characterized by the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings.
Menkes disease is characterized by an increase in urinary copper.

questions.question: Which product is NOT produced in ketogenesis?
Which amino acid disrupts collagen through the formation of kinks in its structure?
Which form of hemoglobin is found in erythroblastosis fetalis?
What protein aggregates are known to accumulate in Alzheimer’s disease?
Which ion is found in the heme group of hemoglobin?
People living at high altitudes have increased levels of 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) in their red blood cells. This high level of BPG will:

answers.text: increase the Bohr effect and make oxygen more available to the tissue.
bind to hemoglobin and reduce the amount of oxygen available to the tissue.
bind to hemoglobin and increase the amount of oxygen available to the tissue.
shift the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left and reduce the amount of oxygen available to the tissue.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of darkening urine since childhood and increasing joint stiffness, particularly in the spine and large joints. Clinical examination reveals blackening of urine upon exposure to air, joint stiffness, and dark pigmentation on the ears and sclera. Urinalysis confirms elevated homogentisic acid levels. What is your diagnosis?
When the velocity of enzyme activity is plotted against substrate concentration, which of the following is obtained?
Which enzyme is known to be deficient in Hunter’s syndrome?
Which condition results from a type I collagen defect that results in the inability to form triple helices?

Jeric, a 26/M, was preparing for a bodybuilding competition and has been consuming raw egg whites to meet his protein requirements. However, after 4 months into this diet, he developed dermatitis, alopecia, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. A deficiency in which vitamin is causing him to experience these symptoms?
Which phospholipid flips from the inner leaflet to the outer leaflet in order to signal apoptosis?
Complex I is also referred to as:
Bilirubin is primarily conjugated in which organ?

A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic presenting with severe wasting, dry and wrinkled skin, and loss of subcutaneous fat. The child appears emaciated. Which condition is most likely indicated by these clinical findings?
When a metallic ion is bound to a non-protein enzyme, this complex is referred to as:
Which is considered a form of passive immunization?
What HLA subtype is associated with hemochromatosis?

A female infant delivered at 37 weeks of gestation presents with severe bowing of long bones and blue sclera. X-ray findings show a crumpled appearance of the long bones with thin cortices. Workup reveals a mutation in the COL1A1 gene. What connective tissue disorder is most likely implicated in this case?
Lactose is a disaccharide composed of which of the following sugars?
The lectin pathway of the complement system is initiated by the binding of lectins to which type of sugar?
Iduronic acid is a component of which of the following glycosaminoglycans?
Which GLUT transporter is mainly present in the neurons and serves as a high-affinity glucose transporter in the central nervous system ?
Autosomal dominant inheritance is characterized by:

answers.text: Both parents must carry the affected gene
Transmission from an affected mother to all daughters
Transmission from an affected father to all sons
Affected individuals have a 50% chance of passing the gene to each child

questions.question: A high homocysteine level could be associated with a deficiency of which of the following vitamins?
The following processes are likely observed in patients with liver cirrhosis EXCEPT

Cody is a 20-year-old male who presents with weight loss, heat intolerance, bilateral exophthalmos, sweating, and tachycardia. These symptoms are due to an increased production and secretion of a hormone that is derived from which of the following?

An infant presents with a heart murmur, hypoplasia of the parathyroid, facial anomalies, and a cleft palate. He was brought to the local pediatrician where he was diagnosed with DiGeorge syndrome. This condition is an example of which abnormality in chromosomal structure?

Nick, diagnosed with Type I diabetes, ran out of his prescription insulin and has not been able to inject insulin for the past 3 days. An overproduction of which of the following could cause metabolic acidosis?
Which one of the following cell types cannot utilize the TCA cycle or electron transport chain?
A patient presents with pale skin, sunken eyes, sore gums, muscle pain, loose teeth, and corkscrew- shaped hair. A deficiency in which of the following vitamins would result in the observed symptoms?
Enzymes are efficient catalysts because they can do which of the following?

answers.text: Catalyze reactions that otherwise would not occur
Decrease the free energy of activation of reactants
Prevent the conversion of product to substrate

questions.question: Allosteric effectors influence enzymatic activity by:

answers.text: changing the conformation of the enzyme
competing with the substrate for binding
forming high-energy complexes with the substrate

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly describes the relationship between substrate concentration and reaction velocity as explained by the Michaelis-Menten equation?

answers.text: Reaction velocity is independent of substrate concentration at all levels.

Reaction velocity decreases as substrate concentration increases due to competitive inhibition.

Impaired copper absorption in the intestine

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of a sore throat, cracks at the corners of his mouth, and a red, inflamed tongue. He also mentions that his skin has become unusually dry and scaly, particularly around his nose and cheeks. Upon further questioning, it is revealed that he has a limited diet consisting mainly of processed foods and rarely consumes dairy or meat. His blood count and peripheral blood smear was normal. Based on his symptoms and dietary history, which vitamin deficiency is most likely causing his condition?

The most common vitamin deficiency in the Philippines is ____________.

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disease that causes an impairment in protein transport in the intestines and kidneys, resulting to cutaneous and neurological symptoms. Which of the following processes occur in this disease?

answers.text: There is a deficiency in the enzyme in the large intestine where amino acids are absorbed.
There is an increase in the absorption of neutral amino acids.
As a result of this impairment, there is a decrease of tryptophan available for niacin production.
Laboratory workup will show a decrease in indican, a byproduct of tryptophan degradation in the intestines, that is present in the urine.

questions.question: A 35/M consults to your office due to fatigue. After laboratory work-ups, you diagnose this patient with iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following lifestyle advice is correct regarding iron absorption?

answers.text: He should stop drinking orange juice whenever he is taking his ferrous sulfate supplements, since vitamin C does not favor reduction of ferric iron to ferrous iron.
Coffee and tea will help absorb iron, since polyphenols and tannins form complexes with iron that allow faster absorption in the intestines.
Limit the intake of milk, as calcium competes directly with iron for absorption via the DMT1 transporter.
Zinc, manganese, and other divalent ions do not compete with iron for absorption, so these minerals may be increased as necessary.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent diarrhea, dermatitis, and confusion. On physical examination, he has symmetrical, pigmented rash on sun- exposed areas of his skin and shows signs of mental disorientation. He reports a diet primarily consisting of corn and little else. Laboratory tests reveal normal levels of other vitamins and minerals. Which vitamin is deficient in this patient?

A fisherman presents to the clinic with complaints of severe headaches, dizziness, nausea, and skin peeling. He reports eating large quantities of tuna liver recently. On examination, he appears to have dry, rough skin and hair loss. Which vitamin is he most likely experiencing toxicity from?

A 65-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation is prescribed a medication to prevent thromboembolic events. The medication is known to inhibit the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors, thereby prolonging the prothrombin time. During a follow-up visit, his INR (International Normalized Ratio) is closely monitored to adjust the medication dosage. Which medication is the patient likely taking, and what is its mechanism of action?

answers.text: Warfarin – Inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase
Clopidogrel – Inhibition of ADP receptors on platelets
